title: The Truth about Outliers Part Two
question_text:
Which of the statements is TRUE?

I. An outlier in a distribution could mean that the data point was entered incorrectly.
II. An outlier should always be deleted from the data set so that it does not influence the mean too much.
III. When describing a distribution, an outlier should always be mentioned as a second cluster.
solution:
Statement I is true. When working with sets of data, large or small, it is possible that a value could be entered incorrectly.

Statement II is false. It is true that an outlier will affect the mean of the data set. But one should never delete an outlier without first checking to see what caused it.

Statement III is false. A single outlier is not enough to be considered a cluster. There must be several values centered around the same location in order to be considered a cluster.

Therefore, since Statement I is true, the correct answer is Choice 'A'.
